title: The standard bearer,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: " But as for the lesser shame," so he continued,  " that I brought on myself and on the cause for which I have been in time past privileged  to suffer, in that I was overcome with wine in the change-house of St. John's, Clachan — that much is true.

title: The standard bearer,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: " So devising evil to my father in secret, he met him at the Clachan of Saint John as he came home from the market at Kirkcudbright, where he had been dining with Kenmure and my Lord Maxwell.

title: The standard bearer,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: I passed by the little Clachan of St. John's Town of Dairy, leaving it stretching away up the braeface on my right hand.

title: The standard bearer,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: " And eke he saw the lads that were pitten doon on the green Pentland slopes in the saxty- sax start frae the Clachan o' Saint John wi' hopes that were high, sharpening their bits o' swords and scythes to withstand the guns o' Dalzyell.

title: The standard bearer,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Ye can ride with him to the cross roads of Clachan Pluck and talk all that your heart desires of Kirk and State."
